radiographic_examinations.findings: Severe bilateral clinically significant macular edema with signs of marked ischemia, including marked hemorrhages, venous abnormalities, and intraretinal microvascular abnormalities; retinal hard exudate exceeding that shown in the most severe Modified Airlie House standard photograph; high-risk proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Considerable reduction in retinal hard exudates in each eye observed 3 months after initial examination (November 2000), further regression noted 11 months after initiation of treatment (July 2001).

radiographic_examinations.findings: Demonstrated capillary nonperfusion throughout the posterior poles with marked leakage of fluorescein associated with the macular edema.
Initial examination showed scattered microaneurysms and small intraretinal hemorrhages. No neovascularization, preretinal or vitreous hemorrhage, or macular edema.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: By December 2000, the amount of retinal hard exudate increased and reached its most severe state by January 2001.

radiographic_examinations.findings: After plasmapheresis, the visual acuity showed some subjective improvement and the left eye improved to 20/100; funduscopic examination revealed a decrease in retinal thickening and hard exudate.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: By September 2001, the amount of hard exudate had decreased significantly.
